text:
WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMING DATE?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Ross
Address: 1924, Warner Ave., Fresno, California
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTION TO FARMING
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1893
Where did you get your housekeeping? Poveshell
Where had you been living before that? (Specify location)
For how many people did you prepare meals? 5
How far was it to your nearest store? 6 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? About twice a month
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, tea, coffee, canned tomatoes, canned beans, rice, spices, dried apples, and oil.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? (Specify)
In what quantities did you buy it? (Specify)
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? (Specify)
How much did you use per meal? (Specify)
Whole wheat flour? (Specify)
Was flour milled locally? (Specify)
How far away was the mill? (Specify)
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? (Specify)
What other grain products did you use? (Specify)
Cornmeal? (Specify)
Whole wheat? (Specify)
Parian? (Specify)
Other? (Specify)
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? (Specify)
How did you grind it? (Specify)
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? .......................................................
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 10¢. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
At what price? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Butter? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Eggs? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Of eggs? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Did you pack eggs for winter? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Hot? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Did you make butter? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Cheese? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
What kind of cheese? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
How did you get fresh meat? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
How often did you get fresh meat? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
How did you preserve meat? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
If so what year was it organized? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Did you use game? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
What kinds? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
For how long? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
What part did fish play in the family diet? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Kinds? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
3. MEATS AND FISHES

In what manner did you buy "Meat" before?

What was the price for a ten pound sack of pork? (Price per lb.)

What brand of canned corn syrup did you use?

What size or size of syrup did you usually buy?

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Butter? (Brand name)

5. VEGETABLES

If so what was it called? (Name)

Turnips ________________ Beets ________________

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apalaces, peans, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? ________________

peas? ________________ corn? ________________ beans? ________________ Saskatoons? ________________

other foods? ________________

To what extent? ________________

Did you make your own vinegar? ________________
6. Beverages:
   - What kind of tea did you buy? (Coffee, hot chocolate)
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (Beans or ground)
   - Other beverages: (Specify)

7. Food Storage:
   - Did you store food in the basement?
   - Did you store food in the attic?

     - Canning?
     - Freezing?
     - Drying?
     - Other methods?

9. Gardening:
   - Did you grow vegetables?
   - Did you grow fruits?
   - Did you grow flowers?

10. Other:
    - Did you raise animals?
    - Did you keep pets?

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ...from town well........................................................

How far was this water from your home? ...200 yds..............................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...by pail..................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. Running water in the house.

12. HAVE YOU:

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, cistern, etc.)

If so, how was this water from your house? (pail, barrel, tank)

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Has any water supply been shut off or otherwise which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving at least where possible.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made my own.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes.

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Yellowish, yellowy.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal, wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From Grandfather's place.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. Oil, gas, electricity.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Coal, wood, from 1893 to 1937.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Bought from George.

What year was it purchased? 1872. Price? Approx. $35.75.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) China.

When did you first see enamel ware? 1895.

Aluminum? 1915.
13. Gas? Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you wash your clothes did you use soap? What kind of laundry soap did you use? How much did you pay?

14. Fuel? Did you use all you own? Did you get any from your neighbors? Did you use any wood? Did you use any coal? Did you use any oil? Did you use any other fuel?

15. Clothing? Did you buy any new clothes? Did you mend any old clothes? Did you make any clothes? Did you give away any clothes? Did you receive any clothes?

16. Food? Did you grow any vegetables? Did you raise any animals? Did you keep any pets? Did you have any fruit trees? Did you have any gardens?

17. Transportation? Did you ride in a horse-drawn carriage? Did you ride in a bicycle? Did you ride in a car? Did you ride in a train? Did you ride in an airplane?

18. Education? Did you attend school? Did you go to a private school? Did you go to a public school? Did you go to a parochial school? Did you go to a home school?

19. Employment? Did you work in a factory? Did you work in a store? Did you work in a farm? Did you work in a office? Did you work in a hospital?

20. Entertainment? Did you go to the movies? Did you go to the theater? Did you go to the park? Did you go to the beach? Did you go to the zoo?

21. Health? Did you see a doctor? Did you take any medicine? Did you have any dental work? Did you have any surgery? Did you have any dental work?

22. Religion? Did you attend church? Did you attend a synagogue? Did you attend a mosque? Did you attend a temple? Did you attend a church of another denomination?

23. Politics? Did you vote in the last election? Did you attend any political meetings? Did you attend any political rallies? Did you attend any political events?

24. Miscellaneous? Did you have any hobbies? Did you have any interests? Did you have any pets? Did you have any collections? Did you have any other interests?

25. Other? Did you have any other experiences? Did you have any other activities? Did you have any other interests? Did you have any other experiences? Did you have any other activities?
16. **SHAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

   Mention any shappings which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

   *Food that was purchased in bulk then, are in tin, Calophane, or packages, paper or foil & glass jars.*

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

   **Breakfast**
   - Oatmeal Porridge
   - Fat bread, Butter & Tea

   **Dinner**
   - Fat Pork & Potatoes & Apple pie

   **Supper**
   - Rice & Eggs, or Canned Salmon or hash, more pancakes & syrup. Buttermilk pancakes.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada?

   ................. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

   *A. Goose, or duck or chicken, don't quite remember.*

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

   *No, we always had lots to eat, always lots of fat Pork & Potatoes Bread & Butter & fruit*

   My family consisted of my Husband & five children—ages ranging from 1894-1905.

   These figures may not be quite accurate, but in the best my memory can recall.
17. Give a typical hearty meal (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest settlers in your area. Give the names and dates of the settlers.

18. What was the first Christmas dinner in [insert location]?

19. How do you ever choose to attract a stranger? Toast! Toast! Toast!

20. We always had lots of food, always the best food.

My family consisted of my husband & four children—after an army from 1894-1905.

Your figures may not be quite accurate, but in the best of times can succeed.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The difference for preparing meals in those days from these, I think are, that we had to use more forethought to keep lots of essential food on hand, such as flour, sugar, cooked it in case of uncertain weather and bad roads, being so far from neighbors or the store, having no phones or many conveniences that we have these days.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I think about 1910 that we began to realize that we could get almost everything we wished for and neighbors began to settle nearer to us.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

In regard to Sec. 22. I would like to say that from 1893 until 1912 we lived on a farm which my husband and I homesteaded between Peace River and Grande Prairie close to the C.P.R. track & there between we got our washing water, & my husband took the contract of plowing the field around & underseeded with the neighbors, & I used to go into Peace River 14 miles once a week. We think in the earliest years with horse teams to trade my butter & eggs for groceries, got four 125 lb. a lot for butter & a 1/2 doz crate of eggs for 40¢ & my children had to go 5 or 6 miles in a buckboard to finishing school but I think we were happier & more content than than many people are today.

Please excuse writing as I am past 82 years.
The difference for purchasing much in their days from ours, I think was that we had less money for things to keep lots of essentials for ourselves such as flour, sugar, canned goods, etc., because of unemployment. We didn't have a lot of money for luxuries or even necessities. Our lives were hard those days.

I think about 1910 that we began to realize that we could not obtain everything we wished for and neighbors began to help each other.

In April 15th 22nd I will take it very easy then from 1893 until 1914 we lived on a farm which my husband bought near the town of Sparta called the C.P.R. Black & White. But we got our living by working on the farm and doing odd jobs for neighbors, and we had 15 acres of land. By now 14 miles away a neighbor built a house for us, but we had to build our own. We had my husband help us with the work. We had my children help us too. We worked hard to make ends meet, but I think we were happy and content. The weather was very harsh and cold those years.

Please excuse writing on paper, please be kind.
The Homestead club at Lincoln, Nebraska, send their regards to me, when my children from here came on the plains during 1915-16, and being very kind and generous they invited me to stay with them in their home. They treated me kindly and when I arrived my children knew the need of my children who were in the midst of war, and they gave me shelter and comfort.

Your very truly,

[Signature]

California U.S.A.
The Homemakers club at Cawth, S.A., sent these papers on to me, when my eldest son has been on the farm, since 1925. I met him very near old times there, suppose they thought I was one of the few left around the River & Ground Creek district where I raised my children. Now the rest of my children are in the States so am living with my 2nd son in Fresno. I am enjoying life.

With thanks for your very kindly wishes and best regards,

Mary E. Roe
c/o W. A. Roe
1925 Watson Ave
Fresno
California U.S.A.

[Handwritten note:]
With special regard to the 1925 flood, which I believe was caused by the heavy rainfall in December.
